Well, I mean, look from a Giu-Jitsu perspective for me, I think I've, it's almost the same as just coming out of lockdown here in Sydney where, you know, we've had sort of almost four months where we've been locked down and for people who were really into Giu-Jitsu, they still managed to find a way to do some Giu-Jitsu, right?
Yeah.

I've, you know, I've been doing it for, I don't know, 12 years now, 13 years and because I'm so interested in my, in my strength and mobility training as well as Giu-Jitsu being something that I like, not being able to do Giu-Jitsu for me doesn't, it doesn't impact me in the same way now that it might have say when I was at that blue purple belt junction where I was frothing really hard about Giu-Jitsu and it was like,
everything that I was doing. And, you know, talking to you, I mean, you're obviously very into it, but I can, you know, you have other interests as well, right?

You're a bit of my type, basketball, those sorts of things, I think you're probably not quite at that stage anymore either, but I think it was a real benefit to me just having interest in other areas because I could, I could do training, you know, I could, I could work on other stuff.

And my view of it has always been that if you can look after your body, so you can be strong and you can be mobile and you can be working on maintaining and developing that, then you're always in a good position to go back to any sport because that's the foundation on which you build your Giu-Jitsu technique and, you know, performance.

That said, I think I took around eight or 12 weeks off Giu-Jitsu as in I didn't go to the academy. And then I started going back to the academy just to hang out, so I'd go in, I'd do my, you know, I'd do my rehab work, which was, which was in that early stage, you know, around where you're right now.

It's pretty, it's pretty light on, right? Like you're not really going to want some off to the side doing that, but I just hang out and get to see everyone. And I think that one, I did that because I wanted my coach to see that I'm still there and I'm still interested.
But also too, it was just really staying connected to the social aspect of the sport and, you know, to the community at the gym.

And it allowed me, it allowed me to sort of start to dip my toes in the water and test certain things. So I think like just being there on the mats puts you in a position where your teammates can ask you questions.
And then before you know it, you're kind of in there with them, oh, hey, let me show you this thing or sure I can help you with that.

And you're starting to do a little bit of duty to be in a very controlled way. And it was in those sort of early exchanges or like, you know, which, which probably lasted for a couple of months, where I started to, I'm just make, I guess, the very clear parameters of what I couldn't, couldn't do, became obvious to me.
So I'm like, holy shit, I can't, like I can't cross that leg or I can't close a triangle or I can't, I can't play butterfly guard.
But I could, but I did realize that I could demonstrate things if I was on top. I could show a lot of positions from side control.

I could show positions from half guard, things like that. So that was really helpful because you're just starting to get an impression of how you can perform with this leg that is going through this hectic rehab process.

And then when you get to the point where the physio says, hey, I'm happy if you want to go back to some drilling, you know, which I, I, I wish I could tell you when that was, I think that was out of about three.
Three months physio is like, you can go back to some drilling and technique stuff, but you know, there's no, like no rolling, right.
So even going back into that, I already knew, okay, I can't drill close guard, I can't drill butterfly guard, I can't, like my, my game is generally X guard and butterfly guard.
So I can't drill those, but I could drill on top passing, I could drill knee cutting to my good side, I could drill half guard and you know, this is kind of cool to reconnect with the half guard.
So I think that all that's really valuable being in the academy, it's good from the social aspect and it's good for also just starting to learn what capacities you do have.
Yeah.

If I think about, if I, I can't really identify when the point came where I felt confident to go back to sort of more intense rolling, because I guess that's sort of the next big sort of milestone where you, where you're like, I can, I'm happy to sort of go freestyle again.
Yeah.
I had two surgeries, the first one that I had, I some rehab really well and I think probably at about six months, six to nine months, I was sort of back training.

And then I went and had to check out with the surgeon and they, I didn't have great range of motion in extension, I couldn't fully extend the knee and the surgeon had suspected that that might be a limitation based on how he had reconstructed the ACL.
He said to me, I've made the ACL really thick, which is great because it's super strong.
The only potential downside is that it's too thick and it impedes the ability of the knee to extend because the tissue that's inside the joint is, is just taking up too much space.
So it kind of gets caught when you go into extension.

And so when I walked into his office that day, he saw that I was limping and he asked me why I was limping and I responded, well, I trained it to last night and I'm limping after, after every night I trained because my knees a little bit sore, but it's no big deal.
And he said, okay, so my suspicion was correct, we're going to need to do a second surgery.

So that second surgery, you know, kind of unfortunately, whatever, right, what it is, you've been there yourself, delayed the rehab process even further and I can't remember if it was like nine months after that one before getting back into it.
But yeah, I'll be honest, I getting back into more intense digits of training, it actually felt pretty good because the knee was quite strong.

And I found that from after the surgery, once I've gotten through that initial acute phase of getting the swelling down, rebuilding the muscle mass and regaining strength, you know, through simple exercises, squatting and deadlifting.
And that kind of stuff, the, I felt like my knee has became very strong very quickly.

However, what I lost, which is the thing that I, that I think is what is not spoken about as much and is perhaps what is equally detrimental to your digits who performance as his strength, it was the coordination and proprioception of that leg.

So it's the things we take for granted where you just, you can pummel with your leg or you can knee cut or you can, you know, you can use your foot, you know, you can place your foot where you want to or you can hook like you just have this dexterity to your legs that you, you know, that is your baseline.
And after you've had a surgery, you just drop way below that baseline. So you end up with this limb that is nowhere near is coordinated and as, and dexterous as it once was.
And I think I realized that's where the potential for me for another injury is is because I'm kind of I'm grappling with this leg that doesn't really work very well.
Does that make sense?

100% because I'm at the stage now where I'm walking and hubby and will often say to me, why are you limping? And I'm like, because it feels weird, it doesn't feel like I have obviously my court is still there was huge amount of after fee in my court.
As most people probably experience and I'm gaining that strength back, but yeah, it almost feels like I don't know how to walk.
And I can definitely relate to that. And that's probably something I've read about a fair bit. And obviously there's lots of exercises that you can do that can help that regain that connection.
But yeah, and I think that's not I have experienced similar thing with my core, we're having the surgery that I had last year.

Just the little things like I seem to completely have lost that connection with my lower and upper body. It was insane. And my surgeon at the time did advise me to sort of take on a different sport to try or take on a different skill.
And I think that's why I think I'm going to do something else to try and get that connection between lower core and upper body going again. I don't think she thought kickboxing was the answer.

But I think it definitely helped. And even when I started working the pads and trying to kick and work the pads when I first started compared to where I was up until I stopped training on a different knee.
The difference my coach was saying was insane. And it was just trying to get those nerve connections everything is going again.
I've always been very somewhat coordinated, always placed for my whole life and I did martial arts as a kid, but not just here at the time, type window.

So I've always been had that good connections and it was scary to think that I was so almost learning things, learning to walk again, learning to my mind said one thing and then my body said the other.
So it's interesting that he talked about that because that's something that I've definitely I've already sort of looked into and there is a fear of what you said the re injury.

Yeah, I think and I think that with the like you go see a knee surgeon and their their perspective is knee centric. So they they look at the knee and that that structure is well the guy that I had a really good knee surgeon.

He's an orthopedic surgeon, so we understand funds and joints and connective tissue that needs are his thing. So I don't know this guy does fuck 250 ACL reconstructions a year or something ridiculous.
Yeah.

His lens is is looking through the knee and so it's like, well, this this piece of this cord is broken. So we're going to go in there and we're going to re attach that cord and that cord is going to read a regain full strength at, you know, whatever nine months.

You know, so great like it's as simple as kind of black and white and it's very easy to get caught up in in I mean, even myself with the I have more of a considered opinion because I look at the body in a different way, but even with that I'm like, oh wow, okay, nine months, I'm going to be good like I'll be fucking back to what I was doing.

And then you have the surgery and you get to that nine month point or whatever it is and you're like, fuck, there's so much stuff that comes along with this that that I kind of knew in the back of my head, but maybe didn't think about as much as I should have, which is like, yeah, they've cut through multiple layers of tissues, which while they've fixed that that cord or that one piece of tissue, they fucked up all these other ones that have now had to grow back together and there's all this scar tissue, they've cut through nerves.
Even just the fact that they've drilled into your bones has caused this huge amount of trauma to the femur and to the lower parts of the leg.
And so you have this whole recovery now from that trauma. So even though the ACL is fixed and in your case, the MCL and I also had a bunch of miniscule repair at the same time.

Even though they've fixed all that and that's all looking pretty good if you look just at that, they've caused all of this other collateral damage and it's generally just accepted in surgery that that's just what it is.

If you're going to cut somebody on and start drilling shit, you're going to cause a bit of collateral damage. But the idea is that you're doing it, it's worthwhile, right, because you're fixing the bigger issue.
So I think that for anyone who is about to go for surgery or considering it, it's really important to consider all of that.

And I wouldn't say in any way that that should stop you from doing it. But I think just in terms of managing your expectations, it's really important to be aware of that because you can get out and you can be at that point where the surgeon's like, hey, Jess, your ACL is great, your MCL is great.
Off you go. But then you're walking out of the office, you're like, my knee still feels fucked. I'm still getting sore. I still feel uncoordinated. My range of motion isn't there.
And a lot of the stuff, I think for most people, you obviously have a very good physical practice.
Like this, right, Taekwondo, Basket, like, you know, physically active through your whole life that builds a lot of body awareness, right.

We probably take that for granted for a lot of folks who maybe don't have as much experience in the physical realm, who maybe take up Jiu-Jitsu, find themselves staring down the barrel of a knee reconstruction or something like that.
When they come out of that surgery, it's very hard for a lot of folks to put their finger on what it is.
I think that lack of coordination and that lack of body awareness that happens after you've had surgery can be really awkward for some folks because you're like,
all the doctors and physios and stuff telling you things are good, but it doesn't feel good. It doesn't feel right.
And so I guess it's, yeah, it's important to consider the totality of the effect after going through such a surgery, isn't it.
100%. I'm not sure what graft you had, but just the fact that I had a hamstring graft, I know there's going to be a lack of all my surgeons said to me,
you could lose up to 30% flexibility in the hamstring. And I thought, oh, and I remember thinking at the time, oh man, that's going to be quite flexible.
That's not going to be good. But at the time, I'm like, no, I need the surgery. I need to get it done. So I'll just, oh, I'll go through that.
But I've had similar issues with the extension. So I've got my flexion up to 125, nearly 130 degrees now, but the extension because of the hamstring too,
it tightens when I sleep, it tightens when I sit. So that sort of stopped me and you need that lead to straight into obviously wolf properly.

So, yeah, so I think I definitely can relate to that in terms of, okay, this is, I need it done. Yeah, I'll just deal with that later. And even now I'm still going through it. Oh my god, didn't realize that my hamstring was going to be so tight.
And yeah, that's definitely going to affect what I do go back to training.

Yeah, yeah, that's, and yeah, I guess for folks who aren't familiar with that, they tend to, for an ACL reconstruction, they'll either use the patella tendon, which is off the front of the knee, or they'll take it from the hamstring, which is on the back of the knee.

And I think generally for fidgetzu players, they prefer the hamstring because if you do have the patella graft, then it's, it kind of hinders your ability to kneel down and put that part of your body on the floor.

So that's kind of makes more sense to take it from the back of the leg. But yeah, totally, right, they steal some tissue from the back of the leg. So that's going to cause issues there because you've now got less mass going on in that section.

After that initial three months, I did notice that my rate of progress kind of increased exponentially in a way.
Which was cool.
So I guess I'm passing that on to you that like, you're still really at the point of the end of the whole thing.
Where, yeah, well, you're doing all this work. You're rehabbing constantly all day.
And you're really not getting much pay off for it.
But the thing is, I think where for people who, for Jim Goa's like us,
we're used to getting results in a different way. It's like you execute a movement like a deadlift or pull up.
So whatever you're working on, and you can see the changes, you can see muscle growth, which is relatively fast.
You can see strength gains, which is relatively fast.
After surgery, you're obviously trying to, you're making strength gains, you're growing muscle.
But you're promoting blood flow. You're getting connective tissue to lay down new fibers.
And connective tissue, I think, takes three times as long to turn over its cells than muscle does.
So the process of rebuilding your connective tissue and fixing up all of that trauma is way slower than what we're used to in terms of normal gym activities.
So, yeah, I think it's normal to feel like the stuff that I'm doing isn't doing anything, but that's just because you can't really see and you can't really feel the difference yet.

And when he came into the gym, he must have come in at around six months post surgery.

And, you know, you might have one aspect of your recovery that feels really slow.
Then you might have also one aspect of it that compared to somebody else has been incredibly fast.

But something that, you know, I see, um, I see a lot of people, um, host surgery who, who really highlight the strength progress that they make and they, and the strength is measured, you know, with typical things like,
like, back squatting or deadlifting or, like, box jumps. Um, typical, you know, great gym movements that, that people use, which I use myself right.

So, and if you could say you could deadlift double body weight before your surgery, and then at some point post surgery, you get back to deadlifting double body weight, that's an excellent, like, thing to check off your list and go, alright, I've got that capacity back.
But what I came to understand for myself was that the strength comes back pretty quickly.
Um, especially for someone who comes from an active lifestyle with a long training history, before you know it, you'll be back squatting and deadlifting and that stuff will be pretty good.
But what I found hasn't come back quickly, and this is the stuff that is typically, we're not as good at measuring it.
And that's the proprioception and the agility. And I'm talking about like your ability to balance on one leg, your ability to balance while, you know, while I'm below your ability to hop or jump.
So to be agile on the feet and change directions. And these are all things capacities that we need for Jiu Jitsu, right?
Um, we would like to have it, you can develop a game if you don't have them. But I find that those are the things that have been the slowest to develop.

And I think that it's very easy to get caught up in, oh, I'm hitting on my strength markers and the range of motion is pretty good. So I'm there, like I'm back to, I'm back to where I was, which is totally not the case.

Because I think that the proprioception and the agility that really speaks to this coordination piece that we're talking about earlier, where it's like, yeah, maybe you got like strong quads and strong hammies again, but you've got this uncoordinated leg now.
It's because of the comfort drama.
